name: 1607_E. Robot on the Board 1
description:
The robot is located on a checkered rectangular board of size n × m (n rows, m columns). The rows in the board are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and the columns — from 1 to m from left to right.

The robot is able to move from the current cell to one of the four cells adjacent by side.

The sequence of commands s executed by the robot is given. Each command is denoted by one of the symbols 'L', 'R', 'D' or 'U', and triggers the movement to left, right, down or up, respectively.

The robot can start its movement in any cell. The robot executes the commands starting from the first one, strictly in the order in which they are listed in s. If the robot moves beyond the edge of the board, it falls and breaks. A command that causes the robot to break is not considered successfully executed.

The robot's task is to execute as many commands as possible without falling off the board. For example, on board 3 × 3, if the robot starts a sequence of actions s="RRDLUU" ("right", "right", "down", "left", "up", "up") from the central cell, the robot will perform one command, then the next command will force him to cross the edge. If the robot starts moving from the cell (2, 1) (second row, first column) then all commands will be executed successfully and the robot will stop at the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

<image> The robot starts from cell (2, 1) (second row, first column). It moves right, right, down, left, up, and up. In this case it ends in the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

Determine the cell from which the robot should start its movement in order to execute as many commands as possible.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2
repair_prompt:
The robot is positioned on a checkered board with dimensions n × m, where n is the number of rows and m is the number of columns. The rows on the board are numbered from top to bottom starting at 1, while columns are numbered from left to right beginning at 1.

The robot is capable of moving from its current position to any of the four adjacent cells.

The robot follows a given sequence of commands, denoted by the symbols 'L', 'R', 'D', or 'U', which correspond to movements to the left, right, down, or up, respectively.

The robot is free to begin its journey from any cell. It follows the commands in the exact order they are presented in the sequence s. Moving off the board results in the robot falling and breaking, and such a command isn't counted as successful.

The goal for the robot is to carry out as many commands as it can without falling off the board. For instance, on a 3 × 3 board, if the robot begins the sequence s="RRDLUU" ("right", "right", "down", "left", "up", "up") from the center, it will execute one command, but the next will make it cross the edge. Starting from cell (2, 1) (second row, first column), the robot will execute all commands and finish at cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

<image> The robot begins at cell (2, 1) (second row, first column). It moves to the right twice, down, left, and up twice. In this situation, it concludes at cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

Figure out the starting cell for the robot to maximize the execution of commands without going off the board.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position
        max_commands = 0
        best_r, best_c = 1, 1
        
        # Calculate the net effect of the command sequence
        min_row, max_row, min_col, max_col = 0, 0, 0, 0
        current_row, current_col = 0, 0
        
        for command in s:
            if command == 'L':
                current_col -= 1
            elif command == 'R':
                current_col += 1
            elif command == 'U':
                current_row -= 1
            elif command == 'D':
                current_row += 1
            
            min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
            max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
            min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
            max_col = max(max_col, current_col)
        
        # Determine the best starting position
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                if (1 <= start_row + min_row <= n and
                    1 <= start_row + max_row <= n and
                    1 <= start_col + min_col <= m and
                    1 <= start_col + max_col <= m):
                    # If the entire path is within bounds, this is a valid start
                    if len(s) > max_commands:
                        max_commands = len(s)
                        best_r, best_c = start_row, start_col
        
        results.append(f"{best_r} {best_c}")
    
    # Print all results
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()
completions:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        # Initialize variables to track the maximum number of commands executed
        max_commands = 0
        optimal_start = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions on the board
        for start_r in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_c in range(1, m + 1):
                r, c = start_r, start_c
                commands_executed = 0
                
                # Simulate the robot's movement
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        c -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        c += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        r -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        r += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot falls off the board
                    if r < 1 or r > n or c < 1 or c > m:
                        break
                    
                    commands_executed += 1
                
                # Update the maximum number of commands executed and the starting position
                if commands_executed > max_commands:
                    max_commands = commands_executed
                    optimal_start = (start_r, start_c)
        
        results.append(optimal_start)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result[0], result[1])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        # Calculate the minimum and maximum offsets in each direction
        min_row_offset = max_row_offset = min_col_offset = max_col_offset = 0
        current_row_offset = current_col_offset = 0
        
        for command in s:
            if command == 'L':
                current_col_offset -= 1
            elif command == 'R':
                current_col_offset += 1
            elif command == 'U':
                current_row_offset -= 1
            elif command == 'D':
                current_row_offset += 1
            
            min_row_offset = min(min_row_offset, current_row_offset)
            max_row_offset = max(max_row_offset, current_row_offset)
            min_col_offset = min(min_col_offset, current_col_offset)
            max_col_offset = max(max_col_offset, current_col_offset)
        
        # Determine the best starting position
        start_row = 1 - min_row_offset
        start_col = 1 - min_col_offset
        
        # Ensure the starting position is within the board
        if start_row + max_row_offset > n:
            start_row = n - max_row_offset
        if start_col + max_col_offset > m:
            start_col = m - max_col_offset
        
        results.append(f"{start_row} {start_col}")
    
    # Print all results
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def find_optimal_starting_position(n, m, s):
    # Initialize variables to track the boundaries of the robot's movement
    min_row, max_row = 0, 0
    min_col, max_col = 0, 0
    
    # Current position of the robot
    current_row, current_col = 0, 0
    
    # Iterate over the command sequence
    for command in s:
        if command == 'L':
            current_col -= 1
        elif command == 'R':
            current_col += 1
        elif command == 'U':
            current_row -= 1
        elif command == 'D':
            current_row += 1
        
        # Update the boundaries
        min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
        max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
        min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
        max_col = max(max_col, current_col)
    
    # Calculate the optimal starting position
    start_row = 1 - min_row
    start_col = 1 - min_col
    
    # Ensure the starting position is within the board boundaries
    if start_row + max_row < n and start_col + max_col < m:
        return start_row, start_col
    else:
        return None

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        result = find_optimal_starting_position(n, m, s)
        if result:
            results.append(f"{result[0]} {result[1]}")
    
    # Print all results for each test case
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def find_starting_cell(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        # Initialize variables to track the maximum number of commands executed
        max_commands = 0
        best_start = (1, 1)

        # Iterate over all possible starting cells on the board
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                # Simulate the robot's movement from the current starting cell
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1

                    # Check if the robot falls off the board
                    if current_row < 1 or current_row > n or current_col < 1 or current_col > m:
                        break

                    commands_executed += 1

                # Update the maximum commands executed and starting cell if needed
                if commands_executed > max_commands:
                    max_commands = commands_executed
                    best_start = (start_row, start_col)

        # Store the coordinates of the starting cell that maximizes command execution
        results.append(best_start)

    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()

    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []

    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        s = data[index + 2]
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))
        index += 3

    results = find_starting_cell(t, test_cases)

    for result in results:
        print(result[0], result[1])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        s = data[index + 2]
        index += 3
        
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position
        max_commands = 0
        best_start = (1, 1)
        
        # Calculate the net effect of the command sequence
        min_row, max_row, min_col, max_col = 0, 0, 0, 0
        current_row, current_col = 0, 0
        
        for command in s:
            if command == 'L':
                current_col -= 1
            elif command == 'R':
                current_col += 1
            elif command == 'U':
                current_row -= 1
            elif command == 'D':
                current_row += 1
            
            min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
            max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
            min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
            max_col = max(max_col, current_col)
        
        # Determine the best starting position
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                if (1 <= start_row + min_row <= n and
                    1 <= start_row + max_row <= n and
                    1 <= start_col + min_col <= m and
                    1 <= start_col + max_col <= m):
                    # Calculate the number of commands executed
                    commands_executed = len(s)
                    if commands_executed > max_commands:
                        max_commands = commands_executed
                        best_start = (start_row, start_col)
        
        results.append(f"{best_start[0]} {best_start[1]}")
    
    # Output the results
    sys.stdout.write("\n".join(results) + "\n")

if __name__ == "__main__":

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        s = data[index + 2]
        index += 3
        
        # Calculate the net effect of the command sequence
        min_row, max_row, min_col, max_col = 0, 0, 0, 0
        current_row, current_col = 0, 0
        
        for command in s:
            if command == 'L':
                current_col -= 1
            elif command == 'R':
                current_col += 1
            elif command == 'U':
                current_row -= 1
            elif command == 'D':
                current_row += 1
            
            min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
            max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
            min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
            max_col = max(max_col, current_col)
        
        # Determine the best starting position
        start_row = 1 - min_row
        start_col = 1 - min_col
        
        # Ensure the starting position is within the board
        if start_row + max_row <= n and start_col + max_col <= m:
            results.append(f"{start_row} {start_col}")
        else:
            # If the calculated start position is invalid, adjust it
            if start_row + max_row > n:
                start_row = n - max_row
            if start_col + max_col > m:
                start_col = m - max_col
            results.append(f"{start_row} {start_col}")
    
    # Print all results
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def find_optimal_starting_position(n, m, s):
    # Initialize variables to track the boundaries of the robot's movement
    min_row, max_row, min_col, max_col = 0, 0, 0, 0
    current_row, current_col = 0, 0

    # Simulate the movement to find the boundaries
    for command in s:
        if command == 'L':
            current_col -= 1
        elif command == 'R':
            current_col += 1
        elif command == 'U':
            current_row -= 1
        elif command == 'D':
            current_row += 1

        # Update boundaries
        min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
        max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
        min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
        max_col = max(max_col, current_col)

    # Calculate the optimal starting position
    start_row = 1 - min_row
    start_col = 1 - min_col

    # Ensure the starting position is within the board
    if start_row + max_row < n and start_col + max_col < m:
        return start_row, start_col
    else:
        return None

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()

    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []

    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1

        result = find_optimal_starting_position(n, m, s)
        if result:
            results.append(f"{result[0]} {result[1]}")

    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position
        max_commands = 0
        best_r = 1
        best_c = 1
        
        # Try all possible starting positions
        for start_r in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_c in range(1, m + 1):
                r, c = start_r, start_c
                commands_executed = 0
                
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        c -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        c += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        r -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        r += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot is still on the board
                    if 1 <= r <= n and 1 <= c <= m:
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break
                
                # Update the best starting position if this one is better
                if commands_executed > max_commands:
                    max_commands = commands_executed
                    best_r = start_r
                    best_c = start_c
        
        results.append(f"{best_r} {best_c}")
    
    # Output the results for each test case
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        # Calculate the minimum and maximum offsets in each direction
        min_row_offset = max_row_offset = min_col_offset = max_col_offset = 0
        current_row_offset = current_col_offset = 0
        
        for command in s:
            if command == 'L':
                current_col_offset -= 1
            elif command == 'R':
                current_col_offset += 1
            elif command == 'U':
                current_row_offset -= 1
            elif command == 'D':
                current_row_offset += 1
            
            min_row_offset = min(min_row_offset, current_row_offset)
            max_row_offset = max(max_row_offset, current_row_offset)
            min_col_offset = min(min_col_offset, current_col_offset)
            max_col_offset = max(max_col_offset, current_col_offset)
        
        # Determine the best starting position
        start_row = 1 - min_row_offset
        start_col = 1 - min_col_offset
        
        # Ensure the starting position is within the board
        if start_row + max_row_offset > n:
            start_row = n - max_row_offset
        if start_col + max_col_offset > m:
            start_col = m - max_col_offset
        
        results.append(f"{start_row} {start_col}")
    
    # Print all results
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def find_optimal_starting_position(n, m, s):
    # Initialize variables to track the boundaries of the robot's movement
    min_row, max_row = 0, 0
    min_col, max_col = 0, 0
    
    # Current position of the robot
    current_row, current_col = 0, 0
    
    # Iterate over the command sequence
    for command in s:
        if command == 'L':
            current_col -= 1
        elif command == 'R':
            current_col += 1
        elif command == 'U':
            current_row -= 1
        elif command == 'D':
            current_row += 1
        
        # Update the boundaries
        min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
        max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
        min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
        max_col = max(max_col, current_col)
    
    # Calculate the optimal starting position
    start_row = 1 - min_row
    start_col = 1 - min_col
    
    # Ensure the starting position is within the board boundaries
    if start_row + max_row < n and start_col + max_col < m:
        return start_row, start_col
    else:
        return None

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        result = find_optimal_starting_position(n, m, s)
        if result:
            results.append(f"{result[0]} {result[1]}")
    
    # Print all results for each test case
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def main():

    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        s = data[index + 2]
        index += 3
        
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position
        max_commands = 0
        best_start = (1, 1)
        
        # Calculate the net effect of the command sequence
        min_row, max_row, min_col, max_col = 0, 0, 0, 0
        current_row, current_col = 0, 0
        
        for command in s:
            if command == 'L':
                current_col -= 1
            elif command == 'R':
                current_col += 1
            elif command == 'U':
                current_row -= 1
            elif command == 'D':
                current_row += 1
            
            min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
            max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
            min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
            max_col = max(max_col, current_col)
        
        # Determine the best starting position
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                if (1 <= start_row + min_row <= n and
                    1 <= start_row + max_row <= n and
                    1 <= start_col + min_col <= m and

                    # Calculate the number of commands executed
                    commands_executed = len(s)
                    if commands_executed > max_commands:

def find_optimal_starting_position(n, m, s):
    # Initialize variables to track the boundaries of the robot's movement
    min_row, max_row, min_col, max_col = 0, 0, 0, 0
    current_row, current_col = 0, 0

    # Simulate the movement to find the boundaries
    for command in s:
        if command == 'L':
            current_col -= 1
        elif command == 'R':
            current_col += 1
        elif command == 'U':
            current_row -= 1
        elif command == 'D':
            current_row += 1

        # Update boundaries
        min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
        max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
        min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
        max_col = max(max_col, current_col)

    # Calculate the optimal starting position
    start_row = 1 - min_row
    start_col = 1 - min_col

    # Ensure the starting position is within the board
    if start_row + max_row < n and start_col + max_col < m:
        return start_row, start_col
    else:
        return None

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()

    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []

    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2

        index += 1

        result = find_optimal_starting_position(n, m, s)

            results.append(f"{result[0]} {result[1]}")

    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position
        max_commands = 0
        best_r = 1
        best_c = 1
        
        # Try all possible starting positions
        for start_r in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_c in range(1, m + 1):
                r, c = start_r, start_c
                commands_executed = 0
                
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        c -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        c += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        r -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        r += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot is still on the board
                    if 1 <= r <= n and 1 <= c <= m:
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break
                
                # Update the best starting position if this one is better
                if commands_executed > max_commands:
                    max_commands = commands_executed
                    best_r = start_r
                    best_c = start_c
        
        results.append(f"{best_r} {best_c}")
    
    # Output the results for each test case
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        m = int(data[index + 1])
        index += 2
        s = data[index]
        index += 1
        
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position
        max_commands = 0
        best_r, best_c = 1, 1
        
        # Calculate the net effect of the command sequence
        min_row, max_row, min_col, max_col = 0, 0, 0, 0
        current_row, current_col = 0, 0
        
        for command in s:
            if command == 'L':
                current_col -= 1
            elif command == 'R':
                current_col += 1
            elif command == 'U':
                current_row -= 1
            elif command == 'D':
                current_row += 1
            
            min_row = min(min_row, current_row)
            max_row = max(max_row, current_row)
            min_col = min(min_col, current_col)
            max_col = max(max_col, current_col)
        
        # Determine the best starting position
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                if (1 <= start_row + min_row <= n and
                    1 <= start_row + max_row <= n and
                    1 <= start_col + min_col <= m and
                    1 <= start_col + max_col <= m):
                    # If the entire path is within bounds, this is a valid start
                    if len(s) > max_commands:
                        max_commands = len(s)
                        best_r, best_c = start_row, start_col
        
        results.append(f"{best_r} {best_c}")
    
    # Print all results
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

prompt:
The robot is positioned on a checkered board with dimensions n × m, where n is the number of rows and m is the number of columns. The rows on the board are numbered from top to bottom starting at 1, while columns are numbered from left to right beginning at 1.

The robot is capable of moving from its current position to any of the four adjacent cells.

The robot follows a given sequence of commands, denoted by the symbols 'L', 'R', 'D', or 'U', which correspond to movements to the left, right, down, or up, respectively.

The robot is free to begin its journey from any cell. It follows the commands in the exact order they are presented in the sequence s. Moving off the board results in the robot falling and breaking, and such a command isn't counted as successful.

The goal for the robot is to carry out as many commands as it can without falling off the board. For instance, on a 3 × 3 board, if the robot begins the sequence s="RRDLUU" ("right", "right", "down", "left", "up", "up") from the center, it will execute one command, but the next will make it cross the edge. Starting from cell (2, 1) (second row, first column), the robot will execute all commands and finish at cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

<image> The robot begins at cell (2, 1) (second row, first column). It moves to the right twice, down, left, and up twice. In this situation, it concludes at cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

Figure out the starting cell for the robot to maximize the execution of commands without going off the board.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2
